sentences.english: No one knows why, but the fell from grace with the boss.
sentences.chinese: 誰也不知爲什麼，他竟失寵於上司。

sentences.english: I bought my mom a new pet, so the old cat will break its shovel.
sentences.chinese: 我給媽媽買了只新寵物，那隻老貓要失寵了。

sentences.english: Vanity keeps people in favor of themselves who are out of favor with all others.
sentences.chinese: 虛榮使人得寵於己，而失寵於人。

sentences.english: This is not to say that Mr. St-Pierre’s appeal is lost on women.
sentences.chinese: 這其實也說明不了聖皮埃爾先生在女人堆裏失寵了。

sentences.english: He was an advisor to Nero until he fell out of favor, and Nero kicked him out and all that sort of thing.
sentences.chinese: 失寵之前是尼祿大帝的顧問，後來尼祿把他趕走。

sentences.english: He had been the king's favourite, and his sudden fall from grace surprised everyone.
sentences.chinese: 他本是國王的倖臣，一朝失寵衆人無不感到意外。

sentences.english: Having lapsed from grace, he tried every means to win back favour again.
sentences.chinese: 失寵之後，他千方百計重新贏得歡心。

definition: to touch on sth and leave it there/to take care not to overdo sth
to churn out large quantities without regard for quality (idiom); rough and slipshod work
to amuse oneself/to play with/to tease
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
dumbstruck and unable to reply (idiom); left speechless/at a loss for words
to rival sb for the affection of a man or woman/to be jealous of a rival in a love affair
to feel hatred/to harbor a grudge
bossy and domineering/throwing one's weight about
to glower (at sb)/to cast an angry look
to reflect on one's past errors
lit. paper has become expensive in Luoyang (because everyone is making a copy of a popular story) (idiom)/fig. (of a product) to sell like hotcakes
making a deer out to be a horse (idiom); deliberate misrepresentation
